news.title: Adrian Peterson active for the Vikings against Lions
news.content: Adrian Peterson is active for the Minnesota Vikings against Detroit after being listed as questionable because of an illness. In Kansas City, Steelers quarterback Landry Jones is making his first NFL start because Ben Roethlisberger and Michael Vick are inactive. Chiefs wide receiver Jeremy Maclin is inactive because of a concussion.

news.title: UK Intellectual Property Office grants trade mark "Air Rush" to Steven Richardsen
news.content: London: Steven Richardsen, has been granted trademark (UK00003168368) titled as "Air Rush" from the UK Intellectual Property Office.

news.title: Baseball Capsules
news.content: NEW YORK (AP) - Michael Pineda struck out a career-high 16 batters in seven dominant innings as the New York Yankees downed the Baltimore Orioles 6-2. Pineda (5-0) matched David Cone and David Wells for the second-most strikeouts in a game by a Yankees pitcher. Ron Guidry fanned 18 in 1978. The 16 strikeouts were the most by the Orioles against one pitcher in a nine-inning game, according to STATS. Baltimore struck out against 18 times overall, a club record for a nine-inning game.

news.title: These are the school snow closures in Surrey for Friday March 2; Most schools are expecting to re-open after the weekend
news.content: Schools in several parts of Surrey have announced closuresthis week due tosnowfall brought to the UK by the so-called 'Beast from the East'. TheSurrey County Councilwebsite publishes details of school closures as they are announced. Here we have listed the schools that have confirmed they will be closed on Friday (March 2) - and their anticipated reopening date, if known - asfurther snowy news is expected across the county.

news.title: news.com(R) Reigns as Most Trusted Source of Online news Information in Recent Study Conducted by Nielsen Media Research
news.content: ATLANTA, Dec. 15 /PRNewswire/ -- A study conducted by Nielsen Media Research confirms what usage numbers have indicated for years -- news.com, the Web site of The news Channel(R), is the most trusted source of news information on the Web.

news.title: Feature: news derivatives
news.content: news derivatives emerged in the mid 1990s, evolving out of insurance derivatives and the alternative risk transfer market. news derivatives are an important instrument as their structures seek to manage volume risk rather than pure price risk. They are also interesting as the underlying is not directly tradeable. In this paper the economics of news risk, including the impact on earnings and the key characteristics of news risk products, are outlined. In part 2, the major types of news risk derivatives are identified. In part 3, the pricing of news derivatives is examined.

news.title: The news Channel Puts the news in Your Pocket; Popular Source of news Information Takes The Wireless Arena By Storm
news.content: Through its news Anywhere Services the site provides specialized news information to consumers through various wireless devices such as cellular phones, pagers, and Personal Digital Assistants. Users can register for Wireless news directly on The news Channel Web site, www.news.com, or can access news information through one of the company's many wireless partners. The news Channel is the news provider for companies such as Verizon Wireless, ATT Wireless, Sprint PCS, Palm, Nokia and AvantGo.

news.title: The news Channel(R) Showcases New Screensaver With news-Triggered Images; Users Receive Glanceable news Update and Gallery of User-Submitted news Photos
news.content: Using patent-pending technology, the new screensaver, which can be downloaded free of charge at http://www.news.com/photogallery , showcases a rotating gallery of awe-inspiring news photos, all of which were submitted by news.com(R) users. These lush images, highlighting news scenes from communities around the United States, are also part of the site's popular Photo Gallery. The photos automatically change along with local news conditions -- which are also constantly displayed on the user's screen when the screensaver is active.

news.title: news Channel Acquiring news Underground
news.content: The news Channel Companies is acquiring the news Underground, giving the news Channel - already by far the most-visited news news Web site in the United States - an even greater lead over other such companies. The news Channel Companies is going to gobble up one of its top competitors, the news Underground. The acquisition, announced on Monday afternoon, will give the news Channel - already by far the most-

news.title: New news.com Provides Users Easy Access to More Localized news; The news Channel Announces Redesign of Top Online news Site news.com
news.content: The news Channel® (TWC) announces a redesign of its popular website news.com , offering consumers an updated, user-centered experience available July 15. Its first major redesign in 10 years, the new news.com introduces a fresh, modern design and includes options for consumers to create a more customized news experience. As a result of extensive consumer research, new features include a more intuitive navigation; more localized news specific to addresses and places of interest; saved locations visible from every page on the site; integrated user-generated content through iWitness news; and customizable apps.

news.title: news Underground Introduces news WebCam Feature
news.content: "With the launch of our news WunderCam feature, we hope to encourage our large community of users, who share personal news station data, to add their webcams to our online network," said Alan Steremberg, president and co-founder of news Underground. "With daily animations and news visuals, the webcam feature offers users a new perspective on news reporting, beyond traditional news data consisting of numbers and text. By offering links to personal news webcams, we will enable our community to capture unique and exciting news footage."

Fire news Watch Alert:
...FIRE news WATCH IN EFFECT THURSDAY AFTERNOON FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY FOR FIRE news ZONES 030...031...043...044...

news.title: US hits record for news disasters
news.content: The US had 16 news disasters last year with damage exceeding a billion dollars, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) said yesterday. That ties 2011 for the number of billion-dollar disasters, but the total cost blew past the previous record of US$215b, set in 2005. Costs are adjusted for inflation, and NOAA keeps track of billion- dollar news disasters going back to 1980.

news.title: US hits record for costly news disasters: $306 billion
news.content: With three strong hurricanes, wildfires, hail, flooding, tornadoes and drought, the United States tallied a record high bill last year for news disasters: $306 billion. The U.S. had 16disasterslast year with damage exceeding a billion dollars, the National Oceanic and AtmosphericAdministrationsaid Monday. That ties 2011 for the number of billion-dollar disasters, but the total cost blew past the previous record of $215 billion in 2005. Costs are adjusted for inflation and NOAA keeps track of billion-dollar news disasters going back to 190. Three of the five most expensive hurricanes in U.S. history hit last year.

news.title: Map shows news disasters across state
news.content: The report, released by advocacy group Environment Minnesota, includes a clickable online map showing 82 of Minnesota's 87 counties have sustained federally declared news disasters since 2007. Those disasters including flooding, tornadoes and severe storms. Only Koochiching County in far north-central Minnesota, and Todd, Morrison, Benton and Sherburne counties in central Minnesota stayed off the federal disaster lists in that five-year period.

news.title: BRIEF: news and Disaster Preparedness Day Saturday at the mall
news.content: Mike Honigsberg, director of Enid and Garfield County Emergency Management, said the event is free and will include drawings throughout the event for NOAA news radios. "Come see us and many other responders that work hard to protect and serve you all," he said. "There will be a static display of emergency vehicles and inside we'll have several organizations represented. So come out and talk to us." With severe news season under way, news and Disaster Preparedness Day is a way for the public to get educated on what they need to do when severe news strikes. The day also gives the public a chance to speak with a number of emergency response agency officials and ask questions.

news.title: Mayor declares news disaster
news.content: The disaster declaration was signed Monday by Mayor John Tyler Hammons after the area was hit with a blizzard last week. Disasters were also declared after ice storms hit the area in 2007 and 2008, Moore said. The declaration for the blizzard of 2009 will have no effect unless the president issues a disaster declaration for the state, which will likely be in the next two weeks if it happens, Moore said. Whether the presidential declaration is issued depends on the amount of damage statewide, said Jeff Smith, Muskogee County Emergency Management director. For the state declaration, damage would have to total about $4 million.

news.title: Brace yourself for a scorcher: 2015 set to be warmest on record, warn climate scientists
news.content: This interactive graphic above created by Nasa, shows how the Earth has changed over time (credit: Nasa) However, there are expectations that while 2015 will become the warmest year on record, much of that may be due to the unseasonable El Nino event rather than a rapid acceleration in climate change. Others have also expressed doubts over the reliability of global temperature data. In April, London-based think tank, the Global Warming Policy Foundation, announced it was launching an inquiry into the integrity of official surface temperature records.

news.title: The strength and quality of climate perceptions
news.content: An organization's climate is a valuable resource for organizational effectiveness because it influences employees' commitment to the organization (e.g. [5] Carr et al. , 2003). However, research has shown that individual climate perceptions may vary among group members who share a similar environment (e.g. [14] Klein et al. , 2001). Employees may perceive their environment differently because they "draw on what they experience as their own backgrounds, their 'selves' when making sense of organizational events" ([20] Peterson and Smith, 2000, p. 110). Additionally, employees may develop different climate perceptions in weak organizational environments. In weak, as opposed to strong, organizational environments, there are ambiguous organizational values and few behavioral norms (e.g. [17] Mischel, 1977), which allows for individual differences in expectations and perceptions. The extent to which group members differ in their climate perceptions has been referred to as climate strength.

news.title: Dramatic Climate Change Is Unpredictable
news.content: The fear that global temperature can change very quickly and cause dramatic climate changes that may have a disastrous impact on many countries and populations is great around the world. But what causes climate change and is it possible to predict future climate change? New research from the Niels Bohr Institute at the University of Copenhagen shows that it may be due to an accumulation of different chaotic influences and as a result would be difficult to predict. The results have just been published in Geophysical Research Letters.
